title: Zechariah Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Zechariah chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Zechariah Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Zechariah Chapter 10.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:1, what should you ask of the LORD in the time of the latter rain?
options: Rain
Fire
Wind
Sunshine
questions.correctAnswer: Rain
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:1 says to ask the LORD for rain in the time of the latter rain.

questions.question: What have the idols spoken according to Zechariah 10:2?
options: Vanity
Truth
Justice
Mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:2 states that the idols have spoken vanity.

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 10:3 says God's anger was kindled against the shepherds.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:3 clearly states that God’s anger was kindled against the shepherds.

questions.question: What came forth out of him according to Zechariah 10:4?
options: The corner, the nail, the battle bow, every oppressor
The sun, the moon, the stars
The river, the sea, the mountain
The light, the darkness, the wind
questions.correctAnswer: The corner, the nail, the battle bow, every oppressor
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:4 mentions that out of him came forth the corner, the nail, the battle bow, and every oppressor.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:5, why shall they fight and tread down their enemies?
options: Because the LORD is with them
Because they have many weapons
Because they are alone
Because they are scared
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is with them
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:5 states they shall fight because the LORD is with them.

questions.question: Who does God say He will strengthen and save in Zechariah 10:6?
options: The house of Judah and the house of Joseph
The house of Israel only
The house of Egypt
The house of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Judah and the house of Joseph
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:6 states God will strengthen the house of Judah and save the house of Joseph.

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 10:7 says that the children shall be sad.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:7 says the children shall see and be glad.

questions.question: What will God do for His people according to Zechariah 10:8?
options: He will hiss for them and gather them
He will scatter them
He will punish them
He will forget them
questions.correctAnswer: He will hiss for them and gather them
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:8 states God will hiss for His people and gather them.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:9, among whom will God sow His people?
options: Among the people
Among the mountains
Among the animals
Among the trees
questions.correctAnswer: Among the people
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:9 says God will sow them among the people.

questions.question: Where will God bring His people from according to Zechariah 10:10?
options: Egypt and Assyria
Babylon and Persia
Rome and Greece
Canaan and Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt and Assyria
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:10 states God will bring them out of the land of Egypt and gather them from Assyria.

questions.question: What will happen to the sea according to Zechariah 10:11?
options: He shall pass through with affliction and smite the waves
It will overflow the land
It will be calm and peaceful
It will dry up completely without cause
questions.correctAnswer: He shall pass through with affliction and smite the waves
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:11 describes passing through the sea with affliction and smiting the waves.

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 10:12 states that God will strengthen His people and they shall walk in His name.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:12 confirms God will strengthen them and they shall walk in His name.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:2, why were the people troubled?
options: Because there was no shepherd
Because of famine
Because of war
Because of drought
questions.correctAnswer: Because there was no shepherd
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:2 says the people were troubled because there was no shepherd.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Zechariah 10:6: '...for I am the LORD their God, and will ______ them.'
options: hear
punish
forget
ignore
questions.correctAnswer: hear
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:6 ends with God saying He will hear them.

questions.question: What will happen to the pride of Assyria according to Zechariah 10:11?
options: It shall be brought down
It shall be exalted
It shall remain
It shall increase
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be brought down
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:11 states the pride of Assyria shall be brought down.

medium.title: Zechariah Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Zechariah Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Zechariah 10:6, what biblical truth would you share about God's mercy and restoration?
options: God will strengthen and save His people and will not cast them off permanently.
God only strengthens those who never fail or sin.
God's mercy is limited to the house of Judah alone.
Restoration depends on human effort, not God's mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God will strengthen and save His people and will not cast them off permanently.
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:6 teaches that God will strengthen the house of Judah and save the house of Joseph, showing His mercy and that He will hear them, indicating restoration and forgiveness. This is supported by verses 10:1-3 about God's care and punishment for unfaithful leaders, and 10:7-9 about God's gathering and joy for His people.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 10:1 teach us about the importance of prayer and trust in God in daily life?
options: We should ask the Lord for blessings like rain, trusting He will provide in His timing.
We must rely solely on our own efforts to solve problems.
Prayer is unnecessary because blessings come automatically.
We should seek help only from human leaders, not God.
questions.correctAnswer: We should ask the Lord for blessings like rain, trusting He will provide in His timing.
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:1 encourages asking the Lord for rain in its season, symbolizing dependence on God’s provision and timing. This relates to trusting God in prayer and waiting patiently, supported by 10:6, 10:12 about God strengthening and hearing His people.

questions.question: Zechariah 10:2 warns about idols and false comfort. What practical advice does this give for maintaining integrity and spiritual discipline?
options: Avoid placing trust in false sources and pursue true guidance from God.
Trust in idols and false dreams for comfort in hard times.
Ignore all spiritual counsel and rely only on personal feelings.
Comfort yourself with anything that makes you feel better, regardless of truth.
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid placing trust in false sources and pursue true guidance from God.
questions.explanation: This verse exposes idols and diviners as speaking vanity and lies, offering vain comfort. The practical application is to seek God's truth and guidance instead of false assurances, as shown also in 10:3 and 10:12 where God punishes false leaders and strengthens His people.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with leadership challenges in their church. According to Zechariah 10:3, what biblical truth about God’s judgment and care for leaders can you share?
options: God’s anger is against unfaithful shepherds, but He cares for His flock and empowers them.
Leaders are exempt from God’s judgment.
God ignores the failures of leaders and focuses only on the people.
God punishes the flock instead of the leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger is against unfaithful shepherds, but He cares for His flock and empowers them.
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:3 states God’s anger against the shepherds and punishment for goats, but also His visitation and empowerment of His flock. This shows God holds leaders accountable while caring for His people, consistent with 10:2's warning against false comfort and 10:6's promise of strengthening.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 10:7 encourage believers about joy and family life?
options: Believers of Ephraim will rejoice like a mighty man, and their children will be glad and rejoice in the Lord.
Joy in the Lord is only for individual believers, not families.
Family happiness depends solely on material wealth.
Children’s joy is unrelated to their parents’ faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers of Ephraim will rejoice like a mighty man, and their children will be glad and rejoice in the Lord.
questions.explanation: Verse 10:7 shows that Ephraim’s heart will rejoice greatly, and their children will also experience gladness and joy in the Lord. This highlights biblical teaching on family faith and joy, reinforced by verses 10:6 and 10:8 about God's mercy and gathering His people.

questions.question: What does Zechariah 10:8 teach about evangelism and God's redemption?
options: God will gather His people and they will increase because He has redeemed them.
Evangelism is unnecessary because God's people will remain few.
Redemption is a one-time event without ongoing growth.
God's redemption only applies to those physically present in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: God will gather His people and they will increase because He has redeemed them.
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes God's active role in gathering and redeeming His people, resulting in their increase. This teaches believers to trust in God's power in evangelism and growth, supported by 10:9 and 10:10 on God sowing and bringing back His people.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:9, how does God’s promise to sow His people among the nations encourage believers in witness and perseverance?
options: God promises His people will remember Him even in distant lands and return to Him.
Believers should avoid going to other nations.
Witness is only for those living in Israel.
God will abandon His people when scattered.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises His people will remember Him even in distant lands and return to Him.
questions.explanation: Verse 10:9 shows God’s faithfulness to His scattered people who will remember Him and return. This encourages believers to persevere in witness and trust God's sovereignty, as also seen in 10:8 and 10:10 about gathering and bringing back the people.

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 10:10 teaches that God will bring His people back from Egypt and Assyria and place them in lands where there is insufficient room.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10:10 states God will bring His people back from Egypt and Assyria and place them in Gilead and Lebanon, where there will be no room enough for them, indicating His abundant blessing and restoration.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by enemy opposition. Based on Zechariah 10:5, what encouragement can you share about God's presence in spiritual battles?
options: Believers will be mighty and prevail because the LORD is with them, and their enemies will be confounded.
Believers must fight alone without expecting God's help.
Enemies will always succeed against God's people.
God’s presence guarantees no opposition will come.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers will be mighty and prevail because the LORD is with them, and their enemies will be confounded.
questions.explanation: Verse 10:5 portrays believers as mighty men who tread down enemies because the LORD is with them, encouraging trust in God's power during trials, also supported by 10:6 and 10:12 about God's strengthening presence.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 10:12 teach us about humility and walking in God's name?
options: God strengthens us so we can walk humbly and confidently in His name.
We can walk in our own strength without God.
Humility is unnecessary if we are strong.
Walking in God's name is only for leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens us so we can walk humbly and confidently in His name.
questions.explanation: Verse 10:12 emphasizes that God strengthens His people so they can walk up and down in His name, implying humble dependence and confidence in God alone, consistent with themes in 10:1 and 10:6 about trusting God's provision and strength.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Zechariah 10:4 says, 'Out of him came forth the _______, out of him the nail, out of him the battle bow, out of him every oppressor together.'
options: corner
cornerstone
cornerstone stone
corner rock
questions.correctAnswer: corner
questions.explanation: The verse 10:4 specifically uses the word 'corner,' indicating a foundational element coming from Him, symbolizing strength and leadership. This is important for understanding Christ as the cornerstone in a practical faith context.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 10:11 illustrate God’s power over nations and encourage believers to trust Him in trials?
options: God will dry up rivers and bring down the pride of Assyria and Egypt, showing His control over nations.
Nations have ultimate power and God cannot intervene.
Believers should fear nations more than God.
God’s power is limited to spiritual matters only.
questions.correctAnswer: God will dry up rivers and bring down the pride of Assyria and Egypt, showing His control over nations.
questions.explanation: Verse 10:11 describes God’s mighty acts against proud nations, encouraging believers to trust His sovereignty in political and personal trials, supported by 10:6 and 10:12 about God strengthening and saving His people.

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 10:2 indicates that without a true shepherd, people will be troubled and go astray like a flock.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10:2 says that because there was no shepherd, the people went their way like a flock and were troubled, highlighting the importance of godly leadership and care.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 10:8 encourage believers to have faith in God’s promise for growth and community?
options: God will call His people together, redeem them, and cause them to increase as they have before.
Growth in faith communities depends only on human effort.
God’s redemption does not affect community size.
Believers should isolate themselves to grow spiritually.
questions.correctAnswer: God will call His people together, redeem them, and cause them to increase as they have before.
questions.explanation: Verse 10:8 emphasizes God's initiative in gathering and redeeming His people, resulting in their increase, teaching believers to trust God for community growth, consistent with 10:9 and 10:12 about walking in His name and remembering Him.

questions.question: Based on Zechariah 10:6, what practical application about forgiveness and reconciliation can be drawn for family life?
options: God’s mercy restores families as if they were never cast off, encouraging forgiveness and reconciliation.
Once a family member is cast off, there is no hope for restoration.
Forgiveness is optional in family relationships.
Reconciliation depends only on human will without God’s mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy restores families as if they were never cast off, encouraging forgiveness and reconciliation.
questions.explanation: Verse 10:6 highlights God’s mercy and promise to bring His people back and save them as if He had not cast them off, teaching believers to pursue forgiveness and reconciliation in families, supported by 10:7 and 10:9 about joy and gathering.

hard.title: Zechariah Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Zechariah Chapter 10.

questions.question: What is the significance of the request for rain in Zechariah 10:1, and how does it relate to agricultural practices in ancient Israel?
options: It symbolizes spiritual renewal and God's blessing on the land
It is a literal plea for rain during a drought only
It is a metaphor for the outpouring of the Holy Spirit exclusively
It refers to a ritual sacrifice to invoke rain
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes spiritual renewal and God's blessing on the land
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:1 asks for rain in the time of the latter rain, which in ancient Israelite agriculture was crucial for the harvest, symbolizing God’s provision and blessing on the people and land.

questions.question: In Zechariah 10:2, why are the diviners and idols said to 'comfort in vain' and what does this imply about the reliability of pagan practices?
options: Because they speak lies and false dreams, showing their inability to guide God's people
Because they provide accurate guidance but the people ignore them
Because they are too harsh and cause fear among the people
Because they only worship one god
questions.correctAnswer: Because they speak lies and false dreams, showing their inability to guide God's people
questions.explanation: The verse condemns idols and diviners for speaking vanity and lies, implying their falsehood and failure to provide true guidance as contrasted with God’s truth.

questions.question: Zechariah 10:3 uses the metaphor of 'punishing the goats' and anger against 'shepherds.' What is the likely historical or cultural referent of these 'shepherds' in the context of Judah?
options: The leaders or rulers of Judah who failed to care for the people
Literal shepherds who tended flocks
Foreign kings oppressing Israel
Prophets who misled the people
questions.correctAnswer: The leaders or rulers of Judah who failed to care for the people
questions.explanation: The shepherd metaphor commonly refers to leaders; here, God’s anger against the shepherds indicates judgment on rulers who neglected or misled the people of Judah.

questions.question: Which Messianic typology can be discerned in Zechariah 10:4 with the references to 'the corner,' 'the nail,' and 'the battle bow'?
options: These symbolize Christ as the foundation and the one who secures and fights for His people
They represent different tribal leaders of Israel
They are agricultural tools for farming
They are idols worshipped by the people
questions.correctAnswer: These symbolize Christ as the foundation and the one who secures and fights for His people
questions.explanation: The corner (cornerstone), nail, and battle bow are often interpreted in Christian typology as symbols of Christ’s foundational role, His securing presence, and His victorious power over oppressors.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:5, what is the source of the Israelites’ strength in battle?
options: Because the LORD is with them
Because they have superior weapons
Because they have more soldiers
Because they have foreign allies
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is with them
questions.explanation: Verse 5 emphasizes that their might and victory come from the LORD’s presence with them, not merely human strength or resources.

questions.question: The promise in Zechariah 10:6 to strengthen the houses of Judah and Joseph alludes to which biblical theme?
options: Restoration and mercy toward the divided kingdoms of Israel
The permanent exile of Israel
The destruction of Judah by Babylon
The building of the first temple
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration and mercy toward the divided kingdoms of Israel
questions.explanation: The verse expresses God's mercy and promise to restore both Judah and Joseph (representing Ephraim and the northern tribes), addressing the division and exile of the Israelite kingdoms.

questions.question: What emotional state is described for Ephraim in Zechariah 10:7, and what biblical symbolism is used to express it?
options: Rejoicing as through wine, symbolizing joy and celebration
Grief as mourning garments, symbolizing repentance
Fear as trembling leaves, symbolizing uncertainty
Confusion as a whirlwind, symbolizing chaos
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoicing as through wine, symbolizing joy and celebration
questions.explanation: The verse uses the simile of rejoicing like wine to depict abundant joy and gladness in the heart of Ephraim, reflecting restoration.

questions.question: In Zechariah 10:8, what does the LORD doing a 'hiss' for them represent in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: A summons or call gathering His people
A curse upon the nations
A command to prepare for war
A mystical chant for healing
questions.correctAnswer: A summons or call gathering His people
questions.explanation: The 'hiss' is understood as a divine call or summons to gather Israel, similar to a shepherd calling sheep, indicating God’s redeeming action.

questions.question: Zechariah 10:9 mentions sowing Israel among the peoples. Which other biblical book similarly discusses Israel’s scattering and eventual remembrance of God?
options: Deuteronomy
Genesis
Exodus
Psalms
questions.correctAnswer: Deuteronomy
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 30:3-4 speaks of Israel being scattered among the nations and God’s promise they will return and be gathered again, paralleling Zechariah’s theme.

questions.question: True or False: According to Zechariah 10:10, the LORD will gather His people only from the land of Egypt.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states the LORD will bring them back from both Egypt and Assyria, showing a broader gathering of exiles.

questions.question: In Zechariah 10:11, what natural elements are described as being subdued, and what is their symbolic significance?
options: The sea and rivers, symbolizing God’s power over chaos and nations
The mountains and forests, symbolizing stability
The desert and wind, symbolizing hardship
The sun and moon, symbolizing time
questions.correctAnswer: The sea and rivers, symbolizing God’s power over chaos and nations
questions.explanation: The sea and rivers often symbolize chaos and hostile powers; their subduing represents God’s sovereign victory over Assyria and Egypt.

questions.question: Who or what is described as being confounded in Zechariah 10:5 during battle against the LORD's people?
options: The riders on horses
The priests of idols
The prophets of false dreams
The foreign merchants
questions.correctAnswer: The riders on horses
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that the riders on horses shall be confounded, indicating the defeat of Israel’s enemies in battle.

questions.question: Zechariah 10:12 concludes with the promise that God will strengthen His people so they walk 'up and down in his name.' How does this phrase reflect covenant faithfulness?
options: It implies confident, unhindered movement and security under God's protection
It suggests a literal pilgrimage around the temple
It means they will travel to foreign lands
It refers to ritual dances in the temple courts
questions.correctAnswer: It implies confident, unhindered movement and security under God's protection
questions.explanation: Walking 'up and down' in God’s name symbolizes secure, confident living under God's covenant and blessing.

questions.question: Which literary device is chiefly employed in Zechariah 10:4 where multiple images ('corner,' 'nail,' 'battle bow') are used to describe one source?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Metonymy
Typology
questions.correctAnswer: Metonymy
questions.explanation: The use of different symbolic items all emerging from one source is an example of metonymy—using related symbols to represent a larger truth about God’s power.

questions.question: True or False: The phrase 'for the LORD is with them' in Zechariah 10:5 serves as the basis for the Israelites’ military success and is a recurring theme throughout the Old Testament.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: This phrase affirms divine presence as the key to victory, a frequent biblical motif seen in stories like Joshua’s conquests and David’s battles.

theological.title: Zechariah Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Zechariah Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:1, what is the LORD asked to provide in the time of the latter rain?
options: Showers of rain
Fire from heaven
A strong wind
Abundant harvest
questions.correctAnswer: Showers of rain
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:1 instructs to ask the LORD for rain in the time of the latter rain, so He will give showers of rain, providing grass for everyone in the field. This reflects God's providential care (cf. Deuteronomy 11:14, Joel 2:23, James 5:7, Psalm 147:8).

questions.question: What is the reason given in Zechariah 10:2 for the people's trouble and lack of a shepherd?
options: Idols spoke vanity and diviners told lies
They were conquered by enemies
They rejected God's law
They were scattered among nations
questions.correctAnswer: Idols spoke vanity and diviners told lies
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:2 explains that idols and false diviners gave vain comfort and lies, leading the people to wander as a troubled flock with no shepherd. This highlights human folly in trusting false gods (cf. Jeremiah 10:14, Isaiah 44:20, 1 Corinthians 10:20, Psalm 115:4-8).

questions.question: In Zechariah 10:3, whom does the LORD say He punished, and why?
options: The goats, because He was angry against the shepherds
The sheep, because they were rebellious
The kings, because they oppressed Israel
The prophets, because they prophesied falsely
questions.correctAnswer: The goats, because He was angry against the shepherds
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:3 states that the LORD's anger was kindled against the shepherds and He punished the goats, symbolizing false leaders or rulers. God's judgment against unfaithful leaders is a biblical theme (cf. Ezekiel 34:10, Jeremiah 23:1-2, Matthew 23:2-4, Hebrews 13:17).

questions.question: Zechariah 10:4 uses several metaphoric images. Which of the following is NOT one of the images mentioned?
options: Corner
Nail
Battle bow
Shield
questions.correctAnswer: Shield
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:4 mentions the corner, nail, battle bow, and every oppressor, but does not include shield. These symbolize strength and stability, pointing to the Messiah (cf. Psalm 118:22, Isaiah 22:23, Ephesians 6:16, Revelation 3:7).

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:5, why will the mighty men fight and tread down their enemies?
options: Because the LORD is with them
Because they have superior weapons
Because they outnumber their enemies
Because they seek revenge
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is with them
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explains that the mighty men will prevail in battle because the LORD is with them, emphasizing divine empowerment in victory (cf. Exodus 15:6, 2 Chronicles 20:15, Romans 8:31, Philippians 4:13).

questions.question: What promise does God make in Zechariah 10:6 concerning the house of Judah and Joseph?
options: He will strengthen and save them and bring them back
He will punish them for their sins
He will scatter them among the nations
He will make them rulers over all nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will strengthen and save them and bring them back
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:6 promises God's mercy by strengthening Judah and saving Joseph, restoring them as if they had never been cast off. This reflects God's covenant faithfulness (cf. Jeremiah 31:31-34, Ezekiel 37:15-28, Romans 11:26-27, 2 Corinthians 1:20).

questions.question: In Zechariah 10:7, the people of Ephraim are compared to what kind of person?
options: A mighty man rejoicing like one who drinks wine
A gentle lamb following the shepherd
A wise counselor advising the king
A rich merchant with many goods
questions.correctAnswer: A mighty man rejoicing like one who drinks wine
questions.explanation: Verse 7 describes Ephraim as a mighty man whose heart rejoices as through wine, symbolizing joyful strength and gladness in the LORD (cf. Psalm 104:15, Isaiah 62:5, John 15:11, Romans 14:17).

questions.question: What action does God say He will take in Zechariah 10:8 to gather His people?
options: He will hiss for them and gather them
He will send an angel to call them
He will build a great wall for them
He will send a prophet to teach them
questions.correctAnswer: He will hiss for them and gather them
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:8 states God will hiss to gather His redeemed people, an image of divine calling and restoration (cf. Isaiah 5:26, Ezekiel 37:14, John 10:27, Hebrews 2:12).

questions.question: According to Zechariah 10:9, what will happen to God's people when sown among the nations?
options: They shall remember God and live with their children
They shall be forgotten and scattered forever
They shall worship idols
They shall lose their identity as God's people
questions.correctAnswer: They shall remember God and live with their children
questions.explanation: Verse 9 promises that when God’s people are sown among nations, they will remember Him, live, and return, showing God's preserving grace (cf. Deuteronomy 30:3, Jeremiah 29:14, Ezekiel 37:25, Acts 3:21).

questions.question: In Zechariah 10:10, from which two lands does God promise to bring back His people?
options: Egypt and Assyria
Babylon and Persia
Philistia and Moab
Edom and Ammon
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt and Assyria
questions.explanation: Verse 10 declares God will bring His people again from Egypt and Assyria, symbolizing deliverance from bondage and exile (cf. Exodus 12:51, Isaiah 11:11, Jeremiah 16:14, Hosea 11:1).

questions.question: What is described in Zechariah 10:11 as happening to the sea and rivers during God's deliverance?
options: The sea is passed through with affliction and the rivers dry up
The sea floods the land and the rivers overflow
The sea becomes calm and the rivers flow abundantly
The sea and rivers are guarded by angels
questions.correctAnswer: The sea is passed through with affliction and the rivers dry up
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:11 portrays a miraculous passage through the sea with affliction, drying up rivers, illustrating God's power over nature to deliver His people (cf. Exodus 14:21-22, Psalm 66:6, Isaiah 43:16, Revelation 21:1).

questions.question: Which nations' pride and sceptre are said to be brought down or depart in Zechariah 10:11?
options: Assyria's pride and Egypt's sceptre
Babylon's pride and Persia's sceptre
Moab's pride and Edom's sceptre
Philistia's pride and Syria's sceptre
questions.correctAnswer: Assyria's pride and Egypt's sceptre
questions.explanation: Verse 11 indicates the pride of Assyria will be brought down and the sceptre of Egypt depart, signifying God's judgment on oppressive powers (cf. Isaiah 10:12, Ezekiel 30:4, Daniel 2:37-38, Revelation 18:2).

questions.question: What does God promise in Zechariah 10:12 to strengthen His people to do?
options: Walk up and down in His name
Build a temple for Him
Conquer all their enemies
Serve as priests forever
questions.correctAnswer: Walk up and down in His name
questions.explanation: Zechariah 10:12 promises God will strengthen His people to walk up and down in His name, symbolizing confident pilgrimage and presence with God (cf. Micah 4:5, Psalm 23:4, John 10:27, 2 Corinthians 5:7).

questions.question: The imagery of 'the corner' and 'the nail' in Zechariah 10:4 is often interpreted Christologically. What do these images primarily signify about Christ?
options: His foundational role and secure support
His role as a warrior king conquering enemies
His judgment against the nations
His prophetic revelation of God's word
questions.correctAnswer: His foundational role and secure support
questions.explanation: The corner (cornerstone) and nail indicate Christ as the foundation and secure support of God's people, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy (Psalm 118:22, Isaiah 28:16, Ephesians 2:20, 1 Peter 2:6).

questions.question: How does Zechariah 10:6 reflect the doctrine of God’s mercy and covenant faithfulness?
options: God promises to have mercy and not cast off His people forever
God demands perfect obedience without exception
God will only bless those who never sin
God abandons those who stray from His law
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to have mercy and not cast off His people forever
questions.explanation: Verse 6 highlights God's mercy and the restoration of His people as if they were not cast off, underscoring covenant faithfulness (cf. Lamentations 3:22-23, Hosea 14:4, Romans 11:29, 2 Timothy 2:13).
